DataElement.preferredName: Renal Cell Carcinoma Other Histologic Classification Data Unknown Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A single character text field to record information related to a histologic classification different than the one(s) previously specified for renal cell carcinoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Renal Cell Carcinoma Other Histologic Classification
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the renal parenchyma.  There is a strong correlation between cigarette smoking and the development of renal cell carcinoma.  The clinical presentation includes : hematuria, flank pain and a palpable lumbar mass.  A high percentage of renal cell carcinomas are diagnosed when an ultrasound is performed for other purposes.  Radical nephrectomy is the standard intervention procedure.  Renal cell carcinoma is generally considered to be resistant to radiation treatment and chemotherapy._Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Cancer that develops in the lining of the renal tubules, which filter the blood and produce urine.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the renal parenchyma.  There is a strong correlation between cigarette smoking and the development of renal cell carcinoma.  The clinical presentation includes : hematuria, flank pain and a palpable lumbar mass.  A high percentage of renal cell carcinomas are diagnosed when an ultrasound is performed for other purposes.  Radical nephrectomy is the standard intervention procedure.  Renal cell carcinoma is generally considered to be resistant to radiation treatment and chemotherapy.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).
